articles.headline: Crypto World Is Rocked as World’s Largest Exchange Rescues Rival
articles.snippet: Binance, the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, said it had reached a deal to buy FTX, amid fears the industry could enter another meltdown.
articles.abstract: Binance, the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, said it had reached a deal to buy FTX, amid fears the industry could enter another meltdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cryptocurrency world was rocked on Tuesday as one of the largest exchanges for digital currencies, seemingly on the verge of collapse, was bailed out by a major rival in a deal that underlined the perils of the industry’s volatility.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Elon Musk Puts His Own Politics on Display on Election Day
articles.snippet: The new owner of Twitter has urged his followers to vote Republican.
articles.abstract: The new owner of Twitter has urged his followers to vote Republican.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk put himself and his politics center stage on Twitter on Election Day.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano, Ryan Mac and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: After a grueling election, officials brace for the aftermath.
articles.snippet: This is the first election in which a substantial number of candidates for major offices are election deniers or conspiracy theorists.
articles.abstract: This is the first election in which a substantial number of candidates for major offices are election deniers or conspiracy theorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pulling off a successful election amid partisan rancor, rampant misinformation and widespread doubts about the electoral system has been hard.

articles.headline: Disney+ Adds 12 Million Subscribers, but Cites ‘Peak Losses’
articles.snippet: The confidence generated by the subscriber growth was offset by widening financial losses for the company’s direct-to-consumer division over all.
articles.abstract: The confidence generated by the subscriber growth was offset by widening financial losses for the company’s direct-to-consumer division over all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Disney emphasized on Tuesday that profitability for its flagship streaming service was on the horizon. But the company’s quarterly results did little to instill confidence, with better-than-expected Disney+ subscriber growth, particularly in North America, offset by widening financial losses for Disney’s direct-to-consumer division as a whole.

articles.headline: Republicans Gain Ground in Push to Take House as Democrats Hold Off Red Wave
articles.snippet: Republicans picked up momentum in their drive for the House majority, but Democrats held crucial seats, dashing projections of a blood bath, and claimed a key Senate seat in Pennsylvania.
articles.abstract: Republicans picked up momentum in their drive for the House majority, but Democrats held crucial seats, dashing projections of a blood bath, and claimed a key Senate seat in Pennsylvania.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans on Tuesday gained ground in their push to take control of the House, although Democrats appeared to be holding their own against hard-right G.O.P. candidates in crucial districts as they grasped to defend their narrow majority.

articles.headline: Despite the Fears, Election Day Mostly Goes as Planned
articles.snippet: There were the usual glitches, some ginned up into misinformation. But voting was largely free of major incidents of intimidation or disruption.
articles.abstract: There were the usual glitches, some ginned up into misinformation. But voting was largely free of major incidents of intimidation or disruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: While there were reports of delays, glitches and disinformation in some key swing states — Arizona in particular — that could loom larger as vote counting plays out, few of the major disruptions that had been feared came to pass on Election Day.

articles.headline: A Girl Loses Her Mother in the Jungle, and a Migrant Dream Dies
articles.snippet: The pandemic, climate change and growing conflict are forcing a seismic shift in global migration. In few places is that more clear than a perilous crossing called the Darién Gap.
articles.abstract: The pandemic, climate change and growing conflict are forcing a seismic shift in global migration. In few places is that more clear than a perilous crossing called the Darién Gap.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios

articles.headline: The House Hangs in the Balance, as Fetterman’s Win Boosts Senate Democrats
articles.snippet: Republican hopes of an emphatic repudiation of President Biden had morphed into a district-by-district slog by Wednesday. But the party still had multiple paths to a House majority.
articles.abstract: Republican hopes of an emphatic repudiation of President Biden had morphed into a district-by-district slog by Wednesday. But the party still had multiple paths to a House majority.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats displayed unexpected resilience in the 2022 midterms, flipping a Republican-held Senate seat in Pennsylvania and rebuffing G.O.P. candidates in a wide array of House seats. But the party’s excruciatingly narrow margins in both chambers meant the battle for power on Capitol Hill remained undecided early Wednesday morning.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: China’s Great ‘Zero-Covid’ Guessing Game
articles.snippet: Companies, investors and global policymakers are trying to divine when the Chinese government will drop its strict restrictions. It comes down to one man: the country’s top leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: Companies, investors and global policymakers are trying to divine when the Chinese government will drop its strict restrictions. It comes down to one man: the country’s top leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the great economic guessing game about China: When will the Chinese government ditch its zero-tolerance approach to Covid-19?
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Meta Lays Off More Than 11,000 Employees
articles.snippet: The parent of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp reduced its work force by 13 percent and extended a hiring freeze through the first quarter of next year.
articles.abstract: The parent of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp reduced its work force by 13 percent and extended a hiring freeze through the first quarter of next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Mark Zuckerberg founded Facebook in 2004, the Silicon Valley company has steadily hired more employees. At the end of September, it had amassed its largest-ever number of workers, totaling 87,314 people.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel, Adam Satariano and Ryan Mac
